A boy walks up behind his Father/Mother and asks "Can I kill this?"
 "What is it?"
 If its a spider or cockroach...squash it
 If its your brothers puppy...not so fast
 If its that odd-looking boy down the road...we need to talk.
 ----------------------------------------------------------
 
 Dr., I want to kill this thing in my womb.
 " What is it?"
It's a human. Scientifically, Philisophically, and quite frankly, logically.

It's a human. Scientifically, Philisophically, and quite frankly, logically.

 
 Isn't a dead person also still human?

Isn't a dead person also still human?

 
 I'll be able to answer that if you can clarify the diffrence between a human and a person.

Isn't a dead person also still human?

 
 I think the definition of human, in context, would be a person that is alive. Dead does not make them human in this context. 
 
 Scientifically, human may mean Homo Sapiens, but there are other methods of defining humans. One of them is their capacity to love and to worship. Worship is not seen in another animal. Some will argue whether or not animals actually love or if it is just a conditioned response to someone providing what is needed.
 
 Either way, loving and worship are behaviors and as my psychology prof used to say......."Dead people don't behave."

Isn't a dead person also still human?

 
 Um... no. It contains human cells, but really isn't a human.

I'll be able to answer that if you can clarify the diffrence between a human and a person.

 
 Dead mind. As long as a fetus is human without a mind wouldn't a dead person without a mind also be human?

Um... no. It contains human cells, but really isn't a human.

 
 What is the difference between the fetus and dead person? The only thing I can think of is the potential for life in the fetus. Is this the key difference?

I think the definition of human, in context, would be a person that is alive. Dead does not make them human in this context. 

 
 As I was asked, you may have to define what a person is here.
 
 
Scientifically, human may mean Homo Sapiens, but there are other methods of defining humans. One of them is their capacity to love and to worship. Worship is not seen in another animal. Some will argue whether or not animals actually love or if it is just a conditioned response to someone providing what is needed.

 
 I believe you have even debated that it is conditioned into humans to be religious and therefore it validates religions. So why is there a need to debate whether animals love if they are acting on a conditioned response?
 
 
Either way, loving and worship are behaviors and as my psychology prof used to say......."Dead people don't behave."

 
 You won't see unborns act this way either. This will not happen for a period of time after a baby is born.

Dead mind. As long as a fetus is human without a mind wouldn't a dead person without a mind also be human?

 
 
 To equate a fetus with the unability to think to a dead body is, well, wrong. A dead person, that is void of soul-spirit would be a dead body. 
 
 The fetus will, under natural conditions will have the ability to think.
 A dead body cannot think.

To equate a fetus with the unability to think to a dead body is, well, wrong. A dead person, that is void of soul-spirit would be a dead body.

 
 I didn't realize that you could determine whether a soul-spirit would be in a dead, living, or unborn body. How can you tell if it is in there or not?
 
 
The fetus will, under natural conditions will have the ability to think.
 A dead body cannot think.

 
 At what point do you consider it a fetus? The moment the sperm enters the egg? A week after? A month after? In the early stages the fetus will not have the ability to think just as a dead body doesn't. In the late stages it will have the ability and I think this is what you are debating here.

I didn't realize that you could determine whether a soul-spirit would be in a dead, living, or unborn body. How can you tell if it is in there or not?
 
 
 
 At what point do you consider it a fetus? The moment the sperm enters the egg? A week after? A month after? In the early stages the fetus will not have the ability to think just as a dead body doesn't. In the late stages it will have the ability and I think this is what you are debating here.

 
 
 For your first question, please bear with me...very new at debating and clarifying myself. You asked a good question and you desrve a good answer. emoticon_xgood I'll need to chew on that and get back to you. 
 
 For your second question, and I'm not familiar in sciences or biology, the fetus is a later stage of devolopment, from sperm+egg, then zygote, then fetus. Stages of devepment 
 
 Now, you said "in the later stages it will have the ability to think..."
 How did you come to that conclusion? Why the later stages of development (fetus)? Would it not be that a zygote STILL has the chances of the ability to think as it develops into a fetus, then a infant? 
 
 Peace

I didn't realize that you could determine whether a soul-spirit would be in a dead, living, or unborn body. How can you tell if it is in there or not?
 
 
 
 At what point do you consider it a fetus? The moment the sperm enters the egg? A week after? A month after? In the early stages the fetus will not have the ability to think just as a dead body doesn't. In the late stages it will have the ability and I think this is what you are debating here.

 
 In response to your first question, Biblically I can prove it, but if you don't believe in the Bible then I'll need to think on that. A good question desrves a good coherant answer :-) But give me a sidebar please.
 
 YOU are WHO you are. The real YOU has thoughts, feelings, desires, emotions. YOU are unique, special, there isn't ANYONE else on the face of this earth that has the EXACT characteristics as YOU. emoticon_xbouncer 
 
 As for the 2nd question, I need to clarify my positon on this. 
 Life begins at conception, then continues through stages of devolpment, zygote, fetus, infant, toddler etc. up untill death. 
 
 I'm wondering.... how did you determine that in the early stages of development that the fetus does NOT have the abilty to think and then claim in the later stages it WILL have the ability to think? Unless you mean/meant:
 
 A fetus early (how early?) does not think.
 A fetus later (how later?) does think.
 
 Thanks for putting up with me!

As I was asked, you may have to define what a person is here.
 
 I believe you have even debated that it is conditioned into humans to be religious and therefore it validates religions. So why is there a need to debate whether animals love if they are acting on a conditioned response?
 
 You won't see unborns act this way either. This will not happen for a period of time after a baby is born.

 
 1) A person, is a unique individual. Could be a syonym for human. Still need to work on it a bit.
 
 2) There isn't a need necessarily but it posits my position more firmly, I believe.
 
 3) Unborns DO behave, however, they are not the same as dead. They have motion and growth. Quite the opposite for death. Also, love and worship may simply not be so easily identified in the unborn. I will not be willing to say they don't occur, although, I am not willing to say they for sure occur. Love I think I am willing to say. emotions are a necessary part of the human existence.

For your first question, please bear with me...very new at debating and clarifying myself. You asked a good question and you desrve a good answer. emoticon_xgood I'll need to chew on that and get back to you. 

 
 Sounds good.
 
 
For your second question, and I'm not familiar in sciences or biology, the fetus is a later stage of devolopment, from sperm+egg, then zygote, then fetus. Stages of devepment 
 
 Now, you said "in the later stages it will have the ability to think..."
 How did you come to that conclusion? Why the later stages of development (fetus)? Would it not be that a zygote STILL has the chances of the ability to think as it develops into a fetus, then a infant? 
 
 Peace

 
 My second question was just to get a feel for period of time in the unborns development cycle you were talking about. I'm not mcuh for biology either and I don't believe a lot of people who I have debated in the past have been either. Many would say fetus and be refering to anywhere from a sperm and egg to the day of the birth. Lets use the following as our definition of fetus:
 
 "an unborn or unhatched vertebrate in the later stages of development showing the main recognizable features of the mature animal"
 
 This generally occurs around week 7-8.
 
 Now we have to define what 'ability to think' means. This is where my opinion tends to be loosely set. At one time I believed it meant the ability to control the body but recently I have changed that opinion to simply being able to support the body's systems. I believe that once the brain has the ability to deal with and all the vital systems of the body that it is then able to process real thought. Based on my research this means that between the week 20 and 24 the average fetus will fall under my definition of being able to think.
 
 Because the unborn is officially a fetus at about 8 weeks and not able to fall under what I loosely believe is the time when the real ability to think is complete until about week 22 I tend to say that the later stages of development is when the fetus has the ability to think.
 
 So as a result of this I am against partial birth abortion and am only for abortion before month 5 at the latest. I would like to see any baby 6 months along or more recognized as human life and any killing of this baby by the parents or otherwise will be seen as murder. I also think this provides a good middle ground between the pro-choice and anti-abortion groups since it would seem that neither side will ever be able to get everything they are asking for.
 
 Concerning your question about the zygotes possibility of becoming a fetus I do recognize that this is a fairly certain possibility and therefore I do not deny that aborting the baby at even the zygote state can be considered immoral because you are killing potential human life. What I do debate though is that killing the zygote is not killing human life. It is only going to kill the possibility of human life. This will make it morally right or wrong based on individual opinion but legally I don't think we can consider a zygote as anything more than a potential human.

Sounds good.

 Peace

 I didn't find a definition for think. Perhaps the site was down.
 
 I'm not really trying to draw you into a debate here. I've pretty much set most of my opinion so all I'm looking to do is test my ideas against the feelings of others. Hopefully we are both able to learn from this type of discussion. I just don't want to give the impression that I'm trying to 'win' the debate by using strawman arguments. If I do use a strawman in this discussion you can assume that I really don't have anything to expand on it anyways since it really is the opinion I have. Call me on it and perhaps I'll be able to explain it but I'm not trying to set you up with it.

 Ok. Then you are dealing with opinions, while I'm attempting to deal with facts. 
 
 Then is it your opinion is that a fetus isn't considered human untill they think? Subjective.
 
 My fact(s) is that life, human life begins at conception and that the zygote/fetus is part of development(stages). I'm being Objective.
 
 If you are dealing with just opinions in this, then you are expressing personal prefrences. Subjective. In other words, I can say that "Bryers choclate chip ice cream is the best". Subjective. True for ME. But if I say "Bryers choclate chip ice cream cures cancer"...you'd be right in saying I was crazy and proceed to give me facts as to why I was wrong. 
 
 Anyway, I thought we were debating. I use facts or else the posts would be meaningless.
